text: The problem with funnels and pirate metrics and the favorites that I love to pick on are MQLs and SQLs is that nobody knows what those mean. It puts every customer in the same sort of buckets. It assumes that all customers and all products are the same. It puts businesses, or they, I should say, puts businesses at the center of the business versus putting customers at the center.
speaker: Georgiana Laudi
context: Lenny asks Georgiana why she calls her consultancy 'Forget The Funnel.' Georgiana explains her fundamental criticism of traditional marketing funnels and metrics like MQLs (Marketing Qualified Leads) and SQLs (Sales Qualified Leads). She argues these frameworks are outdated because they treat all customers the same way and focus on what's valuable to the business rather than what's valuable to customers.
text_ko: 퍼널(funnels)이나 파이럿 메트릭스(pirate metrics), 제가 자주 지적하는 MQLs(마케팅 적격 리드)와 SQLs(영업 적격 리드)의 문제는 아무도 그게 정확히 무엇을 뜻하는지 모른다는 거예요. 그런 접근법은 모든 고객을 똑같은 몇 개의 '버킷'에 넣어버리고, 모든 고객과 모든 제품이 같다고 가정하게 만들어요. 결과적으로 기업(비즈니스)을 중심에 놓고 고객을 중심에 두지 않게 되죠.
text_zh: 漏斗模型和海盗指标(pirate metrics)这些东西的问题，还有我最爱吐槽的MQL和SQL，就是根本没人搞得清楚这些到底是什么意思。这套方法把所有客户都往同一个框里装，默认所有客户、所有产品都一个样。结果呢，企业就以自己为中心在做生意，而不是以客户为中心。
text_es: El problema con los embudos y las métricas pirata y mis favoritos que me encanta criticar, que son los MQLs y SQLs, es que nadie sabe realmente qué significan. Meten a todos los clientes en las mismas cajitas. Asumen que todos los clientes y todos los productos son iguales. Ponen a las empresas, o mejor dicho, hacen que las empresas se pongan en el centro del negocio en lugar de poner a los clientes en el centro.

text: Generally, the lowest hanging fruit outcome is realigning around better positioning and messaging. And identifying more resonant positioning and messaging that speaks to that context that I was talking about before, before people discover that you even exist, have that moment where they're like, "Oh my god, this has to change. This sucks," ties that in, ties in what they care about and what is valuable about your product and then also that desired outcome.
speaker: Georgiana Laudi
context: Lenny asks about the impact Georgiana has seen working with companies through her process. Georgiana explains that the most immediate and common win from her customer research work is improving a company's positioning and messaging. She emphasizes the importance of connecting with customers' pre-discovery context - understanding their frustrations and problems before they even know your product exists.
text_ko: 일반적으로 가장 쉬운 성과는 포지셔닝(positioning)과 메시징(messaging)을 더 잘 맞추는 거예요. 그리고 사람들이 당신을 알기도 전에—제가 아까 말한 그 맥락에서—'세상에, 이건 바뀌어야 해. 진짜 불편해'라고 느끼게 하는 더 공감되는 포지셔닝과 메시징을 찾아내는 거예요. 그걸 그 순간에 연결해서, 그들이 신경 쓰는 것과 제품의 가치, 그리고 그들이 원하는 결과(desired outcome)까지 엮어주는 거죠.
text_zh: 一般来说，最容易拿到的成果就是重新调整定位和信息传达。找到更有共鸣的定位和信息，能够切中我之前说的那个场景——就是在用户发现你之前，让他们产生那种"天哪，这个必须得改，太糟糕了"的想法，然后把这个跟他们真正关心的东西、你产品的价值点，还有他们想要达到的结果都串联起来。
text_es: Por lo general, lo más fácil de conseguir es reajustar el posicionamiento y la comunicación para que funcionen mejor. Se trata de encontrar un posicionamiento y mensajes que realmente conecten con ese contexto del que hablaba antes - antes de que la gente siquiera sepa que existes, captar ese momento cuando piensan "Dios mío, esto tiene que cambiar, esto es un desastre", y conectar eso con lo que realmente les importa, lo que tiene valor de tu producto, y también con el resultado que buscan.

text: So we end up seeing a messy middle there because there's no natural handoff. So pretty well, every company that we've worked with has had an opportunity to improve, especially product onboarding and product activation.
speaker: Georgiana Laudi
context: Georgiana discusses why product onboarding is often neglected at companies. She explains that it falls into a gray area where it's unclear whether marketing or product teams should own it, especially for freemium products. This lack of clear ownership creates what she calls a 'messy middle' where the customer experience suffers, but also represents a major opportunity for improvement.
text_ko: 그래서 자연스러운 핸드오프(handoff)가 없으면 중간 부분이 뒤엉켜 보이게 돼요. 우리가 함께 일해 본 거의 모든 회사는 개선할 여지가 있었고, 특히 제품 온보딩(product onboarding)과 제품 활성화(product activation) 쪽에서요.
text_zh: 所以我们看到中间这一段就比较乱，因为没有一个自然的交接过程。基本上我们合作过的每家公司都有提升空间，特别是在产品引导(product onboarding)和产品激活(product activation)这块。
text_es: Entonces terminamos viendo un lío en el medio porque no hay una transición natural. Así que prácticamente todas las empresas con las que hemos trabajado han tenido oportunidad de mejorar, especialmente en la incorporación de usuarios (product onboarding) y la activación del producto (product activation).

text: So what we did was, we identified SparkToro's best customers. Now, what I mean by best customers is those that get a ton of value from your product as of exist today, pay obviously. They're happy. They're low maintenance. And very importantly, they signed up for your product recently enough that they remember what life was like before.
speaker: Georgiana Laudi
context: Georgiana explains her methodology for customer research using SparkToro as an example. She defines 'best customers' not just as high-paying customers, but as those who get significant value, are satisfied, require minimal support, and crucially - signed up recently enough (3-6 months) to accurately remember their pre-product experience. This recency is key to getting reliable data about customer motivations.
text_ko: 그래서 저희가 한 건 SparkToro의 이상적인 고객을 찾아낸 거예요. 여기서 말하는 이상적인 고객이란, 지금 있는 제품에서 큰 가치를 얻고 있고(당연히 비용을 내요), 만족도가 높아서 손이 많이 가지 않으며, 무엇보다도 비교적 최근에 가입해서 제품 사용 전의 불편함을 아직 기억하는 고객들이에요.
text_zh: 所以我们当时做的就是，找出了SparkToro最优质的那些客户。我说的最优质客户是什么意思呢，就是那些从你现有产品中获得巨大价值的，当然了，付费也很爽快的。他们很满意，也不怎么折腾你。还有很重要的一点，他们注册使用你产品的时间还不算太久，所以还记得用你产品之前是什么样子的。
text_es: Entonces lo que hicimos fue identificar a los mejores clientes de SparkToro. Y cuando digo mejores clientes me refiero a aquellos que realmente sacan muchísimo provecho de tu producto tal como está ahora, que obviamente pagan. Están contentos. No dan lata. Y muy importante, se registraron hace poco tiempo, lo suficientemente reciente como para que todavía se acuerden de cómo era su vida antes.

text: The whole pain killer versus vitamin thing, you always want to be selling a pain killer. So who has an urgent problem that needs solving, not something that they might have a problem with six months down the line?
speaker: Georgiana Laudi
context: Georgiana describes the criteria for prioritizing which customer segment to focus on when multiple options exist. She references the classic business concept of 'painkiller vs vitamin' - meaning you want to target customers who have an urgent, pressing problem that needs immediate solving, rather than a nice-to-have improvement they might consider in the future.
text_ko: ‘페인킬러(pain killer)이냐 비타민(vitamin)이냐’ 하는 얘기에서는 항상 페인킬러를 팔아야 해요. 즉, 6개월 뒤에나 문제가 될 수도 있는 게 아니라 지금 당장 해결이 필요한 긴급한 문제가 있는 사람을 찾아야 해요.
text_zh: 止痛药和维生素的区别，你肯定要卖止痛药啊。就是说，谁现在就有急需解决的痛点，而不是那种可能六个月后才会遇到的问题，对吧？
text_es: Esa cosa del analgésico versus la vitamina, siempre hay que vender el analgésico. O sea, ¿quién tiene un problema urgente que necesita resolver ya mismo, y no algo con lo que tal vez tenga problemas dentro de seis meses?

text: We often talk about it and describe it as the story of how I met and fell in love with your product. It's like this documentary of being out in the world, finding it, realizing that like, "Hell yeah, this might actually solve a problem for us. This might be it." Getting that enough value to convince them to keep going to full value realization, to continue value-to-value growth.
speaker: Georgiana Laudi
context: Georgiana explains how she conceptualizes customer journey mapping. Instead of traditional business funnels, she frames it as a love story or documentary that follows the customer's emotional journey from discovering a problem exists, through finding and evaluating the product, to getting value and growing their usage over time.
text_ko: 우리는 이걸 종종 '여러분의 제품을 만나서 사랑에 빠진 이야기'라고 얘기해요. 세상 밖을 돌아다니다 우연히 그 제품을 발견하고, '와, 이거 진짜 우리 문제를 해결해줄 수도 있겠네. 이거다!' 하고 깨닫게 되는 다큐 같은 이야기예요. 사람들이 거기서 충분한 가치를 느껴서 계속 완전한 가치 실현(full value realization)까지 나아가고, 가치-대-가치 성장(value-to-value growth)을 이어가도록 설득하게 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们经常说这就像是一个故事——我怎么遇到并且爱上了你们的产品。就好比拍纪录片一样，在外面转悠，突然发现了这个东西，然后意识到"哇塞，这玩意儿真的能帮我们解决问题啊，就是它了！"先让他们尝到甜头，觉得有价值，愿意继续用下去，最后实现产品的全部价值，形成价值增长的良性循环。
text_es: Siempre hablamos de esto y lo describimos como la historia de cómo conocí y me enamoré de tu producto. Es como un documental de estar ahí afuera en el mundo real, encontrarlo, y darte cuenta de que "¡Órale, esto sí podría resolver un problema para nosotros. Esto podría ser lo que buscamos." Conseguir el valor suficiente para convencerlos de seguir adelante hasta llegar a la realización completa del valor (full value realization), y continuar con ese crecimiento valor tras valor.

text: You want to reflect them back to them. That is what is going to show them that you understand the problem that they have and that your product has exactly what it is that they need.
speaker: Georgiana Laudi
context: Lenny asks for messaging tips once you understand your customer journey. Georgiana emphasizes the importance of using customer research and voice-of-customer data to inform messaging. Her key insight is that effective messaging should mirror customers' own language back to them, demonstrating deep understanding of their problems and showing that your product provides the exact solution they need.
text_ko: 그들이 말한 걸 그대로 되돌려줘야 해요. 그래야 그들이 가진 문제를 이해하고 있다는 걸 보여주고, 제품이 바로 그들이 필요로 하는 걸 정확히 갖추고 있다는 것도 알릴 수 있어요.
text_zh: 你要把他们的话反映回去给他们听。这样才能让他们知道你真的理解他们遇到的问题，而且你的产品正好能解决他们的需求。
text_es: Tienes que reflejarles sus propias palabras. Así es como les vas a demostrar que realmente entiendes su problema y que tu producto tiene exactamente lo que necesitan.
